questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is being evaluated for chronic headaches, infertility, and galactorrhea. MRI of the brain shows the following finding.  What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and brain MRI showing a pituitary adenoma are suggestive of a lactotroph adenoma (prolactinoma). 

Pituitary adenomas are usually found in adults. The most common genetic alterations in this condition are mutations in G ­proteins (particularly GNAS). 

Depending on their size, they are classified as:

  • Microadenomas - diameter < 1 cm
  • Macroadenomas - diameter > 1 cm

They may be functioning or non-functioning. The most common type of functioning pituitary adenomas are prolactinomas.

The clinical features of prolactinoma include:

  • Due to mass effect - 
    • Features of raised intracranial tension
    • Visual field disturbances (bitemporal hemianopia) - due to compression of optic chiasm
    • Hypopituitarism - due to compressed hypophyseal stalk
  • Due to hyperprolactinemia -
    • Galactorrhoea
    • Amenorrhoea or oligomenorrhoea
    • Infertility
    • Loss of libido
    • Gynecomastia

Serum prolactin concentrations tend to correlate with the size of the adenoma. The normal range of serum prolactin is 5-20 μg/L. The diagnosis of prolactinoma is most likely to be associated with a prolactin level >200 μg/L.

Related Pearl: Classification of Pituitary Adenomas with Associated Syndromes

questions.text: Presence of which of the following features is required to diagnose a patient with pituitary carcinoma?
questions.solution:
The following features are required for the diagnosis of pituitary carcinoma:

  • A pituitary tumor that has metastasized to distant sites, either craniospinal or systemic sites (and/or)
  • Presence of a pituitary tumor that is not contiguous with the primary sellar tumour 

Pituitary carcinoma is extremely rare (< 1% of total tumors). They are associated with activating mutations of the HRAS oncogene.

The diagnosis of pituitary carcinoma cannot be made based on histologic appearance alone. Though pituitary adenomas normally show cellular monomorphism and the absence of a reticulin network, they can have some overlapping features with malignant tumors such as:

  • Atypical adenomas - show pleomorphism and atypical mitosis 
  • Invasive adenomas -
    • Non-encapsulated
    • Show local invasion into cavernous and sphenoid sinuses, dura, brain
    • However, they remain confined to the primary tumor site

questions.text: Which of the following cells secrete parathyroid hormone?
questions.solution:
Parathyroid hormone (PTH) is secreted by the chief cells of the parathyroid glands.

The function of the parathyroids is to regulate calcium homeostasis. This gland is composed of two cell types: 

  • Chief cells -
    • Polygonal cells with uniform nuclei and pink cytoplasm
    • Water-clear appearance - due to presence of large amounts of cytoplasmic glycogen
    • Secretory granules containing PTH
  • Oxyphil cells - Slightly larger cells with acidophilic cytoplasm with no known function.

The following image shows the normal histology of the parathyroid gland:

C-cells or parafollicular cells are present in the thyroid. They secrete calcitonin.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of asymptomatic hypercalcemia?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of asymptomatic hypercalcemia (isolated hypercalcemia without signs or symptoms) is primary hyperparathyroidism. It is also the most common cause of hypercalcemia overall.

Primary hyperparathyroidism results in autonomous overproduction of parathyroid hormone (PTH), resulting in elevated levels. It usually results from an adenoma or hyperplasia of parathyroid tissue.

The most common cause of symptomatic hypercalcemia is malignancy. The most common mechanism through which osteolytic tumors induce hypercalcemia is the secretion of the PTH-related peptide (PTHrP). 

Related Pearl: Causes of Hypercalcemia

  • Parathyroid-Related
    • Primary hyperparathyroidism
      • Adenoma(s)
      • Multiple endocrine neoplasia
      • Carcinoma
    • Lithium therapy
    • Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia
  • Malignancy-Related
    • Solid tumour with metastases (breast)
    • Solid tumour with humoral mediation of hypercalcemia (lung, kidney)
    • Hematologic malignancies (multiple myeloma, lymphoma, leukemia)
  • Vitamin D–Related
    • Vitamin D intoxication
    • ↑ 1,25(OH)2D :
      • Sarcoidosis and other granulomatous diseases
      • Impaired 1,25(OH)2D metabolism due to 24-hydroxylase deficiency
    • Associated with high bone turnover
      • Hyperthyroidism
      • Immobilization
      • Thiazides
      • Vitamin A intoxication
      • Fat necrosis
    • Associated with renal failure
      • Severe secondary hyperparathyroidism
      • Aluminium intoxication
      • Milk-alkali syndrome

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with bone pain and abdominal cramps for the past 1 week. She has had multiple prior hospital admissions for management of recurrent renal calculi. Investigations revealed elevated serum calcium and PTH levels with reduced phosphate levels.  Which of the following is the most common pathological change responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is highly suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. The most common cause is a sporadic, solitary parathyroid adenoma.

Parathyroid tumors may be associated with cyclin D1 gene inversions and MEN1 mutations. Hyperparathyroidism refers to elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH). It is classified into:

  • Primary - autonomous overproduction of PTH
  • Secondary - compensatory hypersecretion of PTH in response to prolonged hypocalcemia
  • Tertiary - persistent hypersecretion of PTH even after correction of prolonged hypocalcemia. (e.g. after renal transplant)

The classical symptoms and signs of primary hyperparathyroidism are due to hypercalcemia as well as increased parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels. The features of hypercalcemia are as follows:

System Clinical features
Musculoskeletal
  • Bone pain
  • Skeletal deformities
  • Pathological fractures
  • Myalgia and arthralgia
Renal
  • Renal stones(Calcium oxalate > calcium phosphate)
  • Nephrocalcinosis
  • Polyuria and dehydration
  • Renal failure
GIT
  • Constipation
  • Nausea, vomiting, anorexia
  • Abdominal pain
  • Peptic ulcer disease
  • Acute pancreatitis
Neuropsychiatric
  • Anxiety, depression
  • Cognitive dysfunction
  • Irritability
  • Hallucinations
Cardiac
  • Short QT interval
  • Bradycardia
  • Hypertension
Ectopic calcification
  • Cornea: Band keratopathy
  • Extravascular tissues: calcinosis
  • Small arteries: calciphylaxis

The features of elevated PTH levels are as follows:

  • Osteitis fibrosa cystica
  • Osteopenia/osteoporosis
  • Hyperuricemia and gout 
  • Pseudogout
  • Increased production of calcitriol  
  • Nephrolithiasis
  • Hypophosphatemia
  • Anemia

The clinical signs associated with primary hyperparathyroidism can be remembered with the mnemonic - “bones, stones, groans, moans with fatigue overtones”

Related Pearl: Parathyroid Diseases

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman was evaluated for chronic backache and abdominal pain. Investigations revealed the following. What is the most likely bone finding seen in this condition?

Serum calcium - 15.1 mg/dL

Parathormone (PTH) level - 2105 pg/mL

USG Abdomen - multiple renal calculi
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and lab findings point towards a diagnosis of hyperparathyroidism. The bone finding associated with this condition is osteitis fibrosa cystica.

This condition is also called brown tumor or von Recklinghausen disease of bone.

In hyperparathyroidism, high levels of PTH result in increased osteoclast activity. This results in bone loss which predisposes to microfractures and secondary hemorrhages. This results in the following changes:

  • An influx of macrophages that form giant cells
  • Mass of reparative fibrous tissue 
  • Increased vascularity, hemorrhage, and hemosiderin deposition - results in brown color

The image given below is showing a brown tumor with numerous giant cells with interstitial hemorrhage, hemosiderin.

Option A: Osteoporosis circumscripta is a large, well-defined lytic lesion seen in the skull of patients with Paget's disease.

Option B: Fraying and cupping of the metaphysis of the bones are classically seen in patients suffering from rickets.

Option D: Punched out lytic lesions of the bone are seen in patients with multiple myeloma.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman is referred with recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia. During the evaluation, she is found to have high serum levels of insulin. Measurement of which of the following can help in reaching the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of hypoglycemia due to hyperinsulinemia. As C-peptide is a marker of endogenous insulin secretion, its levels would help in identifying the source of insulin:

  • High C-peptide -  excess insulin production (insulinoma)
  • Normal/ low C-peptide - exogenous insulin administration (factitious disorder)

The precursor molecule of insulin is pre-proinsulin, which gets cleaved to form proinsulin. This proinsulin gets cleaved to form insulin and C-peptide (by-product). Hence, both are secreted in equimolar quantities during insulin secretion. Hence, the level of C-peptide corresponds to the level of endogenous insulin.

The levels of C-peptide decrease with the loss of β-cell mass in type 1 diabetes.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following chromosomal anomalies are least likely to develop diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Edward's syndrome or trisomy 18 is not associated with diabetes mellitus.

Genetic syndromes associated with diabetes mellitus include:

  • Down's syndrome (trisomy 21)
  • Klinefelter's syndrome (XXY karyotype)
  • Turner's syndrome (XO karyotype)
  • Prader–Willi syndrome (deletion of paternal chromosome 15)

Other causes of diabetes mellitus include:

  • Genetic defects in insulin action -
    • Type A insulin resistance
    • Lipoatrophic diabetes
  • Exocrine pancreatic defects - 
    • Chronic pancreatitis
    • Pancreatectomy/trauma
    • Neoplasia
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Hemochromatosis
    • Fibrocalculous pancreatopathy
  • Endocrinopathies - 
    • Acromegaly
    • Cushing syndrome
    • Hyperthyroidism
    • Pheochromocytoma
    • Glucagonoma
  • Infections - 
    • Cytomegalovirus
    • Coxsackie B virus
    • Congenital rubella

questions.text: A pathologist is studying a Congo red-stained slide of pancreatic tissue. He observes it under polarized light and notes the following finding. This finding is commonly associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The image shows a Congo red-stained biopsy specimen with apple-green birefringence under polarized microscopy. It is indicative of amyloid accumulation within the pancreatic islets. This is commonly associated with type 2 diabetes mellitus. 

Amyloid deposition begins in and around capillaries and between cells. In advanced stages, the islets may be virtually obliterated and fibrosis may also be observed.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a detrimental effect of advanced glycation end-products in patients suffering from diabetes mellitus?

choices.text: Deposition of excess basement membrane material due to TGF-β release
Generation of reactive oxygen species in endothelial cells
Increased anticoagulant effect on endothelial cells and macrophages
Increase in vascular smooth muscle cells and extracellular matrix

questions.solution:
Advanced glycation end products (AGEs) result in increased procoagulant effects on endothelial cells and macrophages, not anticoagulant effects. 

AGEs are formed by nonenzymatic reactions between intracellular glucose-derived dicarbonyl precursors with the amino groups of proteins. They bind to a specific receptor (RAGE) that is expressed on inflammatory cells (macrophages and T cells), endothelium, and vascular smooth muscle.

The detrimental effects of the AGE-RAGE signalling axis within the vascular compartment include:

  • Release of cytokines and growth factors, including TGF-β - leads to deposition of excess basement membrane material
  • Generation of reactive oxygen species in endothelial cells.
  • Increased procoagulant activity on endothelial cells and macrophages.
  • Enhanced proliferation of vascular smooth muscle cells and synthesis of extracellular matrix

These effects are responsible for the microvascular and macrovascular complications in diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: What is the most common pancreatic endocrine neoplasm?
questions.solution:
Insulinoma (β­-cell tumors) is the most common pancreatic endocrine neoplasm. It produces sufficient insulin to induce clinically significant hypoglycemia.

The three most common and distinctive clinical syndromes associated with functional pancreatic endocrine neoplasms are as follows:

  • Hyperinsulinism
  • Zollinger–Ellison syndrome (hypergastrinemia)
  • Multiple endocrine neoplasias (MEN)

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Endocrine neoplasm

Clinical features

Glucagonoma

Mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia

Insulinoma

Clinically significant hypoglycemia

Gastrinoma

Peptic ulceration often unresponsive to therapy and in unusual locations such as the jejunum

Somatostatinoma

Diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, steatorrhea, and hypochlorhydria

VIPoma

Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria, or WDHA syndrome

Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting endocrine tumors

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms

Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.

In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

Related Pearl: Whipple's Triad

Whipple’s triad describes the clinical symptoms of insulinoma.

  • Symptoms of hypoglycemia after fasting or exercise
  • Plasma glucose levels <2.8 mmol/L or 50 mg/dL.
  • Relief of symptoms after intravenous administration of glucose.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man was referred to a higher center for further evaluation of peptic ulcer disease refractory to high doses of proton pump inhibitors. There is a history of pituitary and parathyroid tumors in his family members. Serum gastrin level was found to be 1690 pg/ml (normal < 100) and a neuroendocrine tumor is suspected. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: It is associated with intractable jejunal ulcers
This patient likely has a solitary tumor
Tumors usually originate in Passaro's triangle

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a gastrin-producing tumor or gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome). The family history of pituitary and parathyroid tumors is suggestive of MEN1 syndrome. This syndrome is associated with multifocal gastrinomas.

On the other hand, sporadic gastrinomas are usually single.

Gastrinomas usually arise in the duodenum, peripancreatic soft tissues, pancreas. The site of origin is the duodenum when ZES is associated with MEN1. Most tumors are locally invasive and metastasize early. 

Hypergastrinemia gives rise to extreme gastric acid secretion and peptic ulceration, that is refractory to proton pump inhibitors. It results in multiple ulcers in duodenum, stomach, and uncommon areas like jejunum.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic tests in Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

  • Gastric pH <2.5 and
  • Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.

Other tests:

  • BAO >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)
  • BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

(BAO=Basal acid output; MAO=Maximal acid output)

For localization

  • Initial investigation - CT or MRI
  • Best investigation - Endoscopic ultrasound
  • If the tumor is not localized - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.

questions.text: A patient with longstanding diabetes mellitus came with complaints of bulky stools. Ultrasound abdomen showed the presence of multiple gallstones. Hypersecretion of which of the following leads to this presentation?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of a δ-cell tumor or somatostatinoma. It results in hypersecretion of somatostatin.

Somatostatin inhibits pancreatic and biliary secretions. Patients with somatostatinoma usually present with vague abdominal pain along with the triad of:

  • Gallstones - due to bile stasis
  • Diabetes mellitus - due to inhibition of insulin secretion
  • Steatorrhea - due to inhibition of pancreatic exocrine secretion and bile secretion

questions.text: A patient presented with profuse watery diarrhoea and muscle cramps for the past few weeks. The diarrhoea was intractable to antibiotics and stool culture was negative for organisms. He also complained of indigestion and frequent bloating. On investigation, he was found to have microcytic hypochromic anaemia. Serum potassium was 2.4 mmol/L. Upper GI endoscopy was normal. Excess of which of the following hormones leads to this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of WDHA syndrome. It is due to hypersecretion of VIP (vasoactive-intestinal peptide).

WDHA syndrome includes the following features:

  • Watery diarrhea
  • Hypokalemia (Serum K+< 3.5 mmol/L)
  • Achlorhydria (bloating, indigestion, iron deficiency)

Neural crest tumors, such as neuroblastomas, ganglioneuroblastoma, ganglioneuromas, and pheochromocytomas can also be associated with VIPoma syndrome.
